I photograph the ISS by manually moving my scope. I already have a website dedicated to it and on that site I share other people's photograph too. I highly recommend to look up Philip Smith and his work. If you contact him, I'm almost sure he could help you in unsing smooth tracking during future rocket launch. The booster isn't actually resting in pieces, it is still living. It's B1050 style just 620km offshore.

A cable harness clearly floated off stage 1 just beside the grid fin at 05-57 on the Space-X Mission Clock. It was definitely NOT the usual Ice. You can tell by it's flexibility as it bumps off the grid fin. There's no way that's normal.
(My best guess: as the only cabling around there is in the utility conduit and that's unlikely to have opened up, maybe a piece of the connecting cables that we see lasing around inside the inter-stage at separation broke off, traveled down the fuselage, and got stuck near the grid fin for a short while (until the cold gas thruster blew it away)
I wouldn't be surprised if the engineers knew that they had loss of command control on the way down and that they'd have to drop it into the ocean.
Anyways, this is probably good. We need failures to test out as many failure modes as possible.
Would be interesting to have a video of bird reactions

A whole lot wrong in the video description??  SpaceX $50B per year revenue is based on 40.000 Sats .. profit potential of that is probably $5-10B per year (no where near enough to fund a Mars colony, LOL). Using only Falcon 9, SpaceX must launch about ONE Falcon 9 per DAY, for the next several years. Their launch pace must be greatly accelerated, because the average Sat life is only 4 years .. with a 40K network, 30 Sats per day will dropping from orbit.. just to maintain the Network will require several Falcon 9 launches per week .. and therefore the operational costs will be rather high .. UNLESS, SpaceX can get Starship deployed quickly!!! .. which IMO, is the main purpose behind Super Heavy + Starship right now, the future viability of Starlink depends on Starship getting operational within 2 years.  After that, Starship may morph into other cargo and LEO mission ops for NASA/ESA and others .. and eventually become human rated and replace SLS/Orion about 10-15 years from now.  So go ahead and give your negative replies below, because "Elon said..." ... and remember, years from now, you heard all this from me first!!
